- *For the material, see [gold (material)](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)").*

In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, a **zorkmid** is a single unit of currency, and a **gold piece**, $, is the coinage used and has a value of 1 zorkmid.

Gold pieces are a special type of [object](/wiki/Object "Object"): they have weight and take up an inventory slot when dropping items, but have no [BUC](/wiki/BUC "BUC") status. The inventory slot they occupy is represented by their symbol is **$**; the abbreviations **zm** and **zk** are sometimes appended to a number as a currency symbol. When referred to while [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating"), they are given [various other names](/wiki/Hallucinatory_currency "Hallucinatory currency").

A gold piece weighs 0.01 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum") (arbitrary units of measure); since these units have no formal name, it is common to consider 100 gold pieces the base unit of weight. All weight figures given in spoilers and on this wiki are in units of 100 gold pieces.

## Generation

Gold is an incredibly common sight in the Dungeons of Doom, and can be found on the floor, in containers and the inventory of other monsters; see the section below for more information regarding monster interactions with gold. [Vaults](/wiki/Vault "Vault") containing gold are generated on some floors; [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios") has a massive well-guarded repository of gold and can only be accessed through a vault portal. In addition, [treasure zoos](/wiki/Treasure_zoo "Treasure zoo") and [leprechaun halls](/wiki/Leprechaun_hall "Leprechaun hall") are generated with gold on most of their tiles, along with sleeping monsters on top of them.

Both the [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer") and [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") start with a significant amount of gold. [Gold golems](/wiki/Gold_golem "Gold golem") will leave behind a pile of gold upon death.

### Gold and monsters

Monsters that [love gold](/wiki/Gold_lover "Gold lover") have a 1⁄5 chance of being generated with some in their inventory, and hostile gold lovers will try to pick up any gold they come across; this includes anything mimicking the appearance of gold, such as a [mimic](/wiki/Mimic "Mimic") or a player who has eaten a mimic corpse. The amount of gold given is determined by die roll: the number of dice rolled is the current [dungeon level](/wiki/Dungeon_level "Dungeon level"), with the usual adjustments for players who are carrying the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor") or else in the [endgame](/wiki/Endgame "Endgame"). If the monster already has some items in its inventory, a d5 is used; otherwise, the roll uses d10. A monster on dungeon level 10 with no items might get *10d10* zorkmids, whereas a monster on floor 20 with some items might get *20d5* zorkmids.

There are some exceptions to the above formula. [Leprechauns](/wiki/Leprechaun "Leprechaun") always receive gold, and always roll a number of d30 equal to the dungeon level; [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") always get gold and receive 20–29 zorkmids. Another less exceptional case is an ordinary [soldier](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") - they will only be generated with gold 1/13 of the time.

## Description

Gold is used to buy items from [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), and is also used for other similar transactions, such as buying [intrinsic protection](/wiki/Intrinsic_protection "Intrinsic protection") and other benefits from the [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") priest or consultations from [the Oracle](/wiki/Oracle_\(monster\) "Oracle (monster)"); dropping gold on any of the tiles of a shop will establish credit in that shop only.

### Shopping

Gold can be used to purchase items from shops or else establish credit by dropping the gold on the floor inside the shop. You can also pacify angry [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") by paying for stolen items - see their article for more information.

### Temple priests

- *Main article: [Aligned priests#Chatting to a priest](/wiki/Aligned_priests#Chatting_to_a_priest "Aligned priests")*

If you [chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat") with a peaceful temple priest while carrying gold in your open inventory, the priest will prompt you for a contribution to the temple. Donating a specific amount of gold to them can net several beneficial effects, such as the aforementioned protection or alignment points; see that article for more information specific to donations.

### Bribery

- *Main article: [Bribe](/wiki/Bribe "Bribe")*

Hostile shopkeepers and specific monsters such as [unique demons](/wiki/Unique_demon "Unique demon") and [Yendorian Army](/wiki/Yendorian_Army "Yendorian Army") soldiers may accept bribes of gold to leave the player alone, turning them peaceful.

## Strategy

Acquiring a decent amount of gold is usually an early-game objective for most players in order to purchase items from shops. Accordingly, collecting gold becomes less urgent once the player has assembled a solid enough kit to progress further into the game and can reliably obtain more items by killing monsters, [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling"), [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice"), etc. Some players may then opt to buy protection at a later point; gold is sometimes put to more unorthodox uses, which are mentioned alongside the more common and general uses below.

### Shops

In Minetown, pacifying an angry shopkeeper will also pacify Minetown's [watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") if they are angry at you; this is commonly done by stealing a cheap item or a single piece of gold.

[Credit cloning](/wiki/Credit_cloning "Credit cloning") is a means of taking the shopkeeper's gold using your own gold; specifically, this is done by dropping your gold or a container with your gold in it to establish credit, then using your pet or a gold-loving monster to steal it back from the shop. You can then retrieve the gold and keep your store credit. See that article for more detailed information.

One consistently applicable use for gold in shops is detecting hidden mimics: throwing projectiles and other items in shops will automatically sell them, and no player enjoys having to buy back their valuable stack of [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") or [darts](/wiki/Dart "Dart"). Searching can uncover mimics easily, but will also result in the larger ones sticking to you; throwing a single gold piece in the direction of a suspected mimic will reveal it safely, and the gold will simply give you store credit.

### Combat

Some gold-loving monsters such as leprechauns and orcs can potentially be distracted by thrown or strategically placed gold, potentially allowing you to distance yourself or escape from them in a pinch, or else positioning them to maximize damage from certain attacks, e.g. a rebounded [magic missile](/wiki/Magic_missile "Magic missile"). They can also be used to distract some [hiding](/wiki/Hiding "Hiding") monsters, such as [snakes](/wiki/Snake "Snake") and [cave spiders](/wiki/Cave_spider "Cave spider").

### Conducts

[Pacifists](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") can use gold to gain experience points and [exercise](/wiki/Exercise "Exercise") [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") by consulting the Oracle, and will want to obtain as much protection as they possibly can, as early as they can. They can also use it as a means of detecting monsters in dark corridors - it will produce the usual hit/miss messages without doing any actual damage.

### Polypiling

Some players drop gold on top of piles used for [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") to reduce the chance of creating a [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") from other items; at the same time, too many gold objects in a pile may result in a [gold golem](/wiki/Gold_golem "Gold golem").

### Other uses

In addition to the above, players use gold pieces to:

- Mark bubbles on the [Plane of Water](/wiki/Plane_of_Water "Plane of Water") that you've already searched for the portal in;
- [Weight-test](/wiki/Identification#Weight_identification "Identification") items, e.g. suspected [levitation boots](/wiki/Levitation_boots "Levitation boots") or a [loadstone](/wiki/Loadstone "Loadstone") in a chest;
- Generate [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") room monsters by #[looting](/wiki/Loot "Loot") the throne while confused and carrying gold;
- For style points, #[chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat") with the [high priest](/wiki/High_priest "High priest") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") right before ascending;
- Feed a pet [metallivore](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore"), or eat gold if polymorphed into one;
- Polymorph it for a gold golem;
- Make a [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") fall down [stairs](/wiki/Stairs "Stairs") by throwing gold onto its square

## Origin

The name "zorkmid" is a reference to the Infocom [text adventure](/wiki/Text_adventure "Text adventure") series, *Zork*; the zorkmid is the currency used by the monarchy of Quendor, and often carries a likeness of the seventh king of the Flathead dynasty, Lord Dimwit Flathead.

## Messages

- 1 Zorkmid. 857 GUE. In Frobs we trust.

  [YAFM](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM") generated from selecting your gold in the [read](/wiki/Read "Read") command's extended list.

## See also

- [Negative gold](/wiki/Negative_gold "Negative gold")

## Encyclopedia entry (for "gold")

A metal of characteristic yellow colour, the most precious metal used as a common commercial medium of exchange. Symbol, Au; at. no. 79; at. wt. 197.2. It is the most malleable and ductile of all metals, and very heavy (sp. gr., 19.3). It is quite unalterable by heat, moisture, and most corrosive agents, and therefore well suited for its use in coin and jewelry.

\[ Webster's New International Dictionary  
                           of the English Language, Second Edition ]
